answer: Yale University [accept Yale School of Architecture]

question: Le Corbusier [or Charles-Edouard Jeanneret-Gris]. Le Corbusier designed this white, reinforced-concrete building in Poissy, France. It is built on stilts  and has a square floor plan.

Villa Savoye. Le Corbusier planned the design of the city Chandigarh in this country. Architectural monuments in  this country include the Brihadeeswarar temple in Thanjavur and the Taj Mahal in Agra.

Peace of God movement [or Pax Dei; or Paix de Dieu; accept Truce of God or Treuga Dei]. The Peace of God was strongly supported by this Benedictine super-monastery that gained power through a system of dependent priories. Peter the Venerable was a leader of this abbey, which promoted namesake anti-simony reforms in the 11th century.
answer: Cluny Abbey [accept Cluniac reforms or Clunian reforms]

question: autism [or autism spectrum disorder]. Kanner first formulated the bogus "refrigerator mother" theory of autism that was popularized by this UChicago psychologist, who analyzed fairy tales in Freudian terms in The Uses of Enchantment.

Name this phenotype possessed by Drosophila that can form an active, dimeric transcription factor because they possess sis-A and sis-B in excess of deadpan. Flies with this phenotype produce the proteins TRA and SXL.
Disgrace. Disgrace is a novel by this South African author, who also wrote about a hare-lipped gardener who travels to his mother's birthplace in The Life and Times of Michael K.
John Maxwell Coetzee. In this Coetzee novel, Colonel Joll, sent by the Third Bureau, tortures members of the title group. The Magistrate is tortured by Joll's soldiers when he objects.
The Watsons. In Jane Austen's complete novel Northanger Abbey, this protagonist marries Henry Tilney despite the faux pas of accusing his father of murder for no reason.

Stanley Milgram's obedience experiment [accept either]. Stanley Milgram was mentored by Solomon Asch, who worked on this psychological concept. This term refers to the act of matching one's behavior and attitudes to that of a group.

Zadok the Priest. Another of Handel's coronation anthems, My Heart is Inditing, uses a text also set by this earlier composer. This composer wrote a G-Minor Chacony for strings, as well as the operas The Faery-Queen and Dido and Aeneas.

Name this American economist who gave the first algebraic formulation of the equation of exchange, and whose namesake hypothesis states that the real interest rate is stable and unaffected by monetary actions.
sunyata. Nagarjuna and other Madhyamaka philosophers belong to this religion, which takes annatta, or non-self, as a central concept.

Buddhism [accept Mahayana Buddhism]. Modern commentators have noted similarities between Buddhist views on the self and this philosopher's bundle theory, introduced in a work which advocated a "science of man" and claimed that reason is slave to the passions.

Stigma: Notes on the Management of Spoiled Identity. Stigma and Asylums were written by this sociologist, a proponent of symbolic interactionism who applied dramaturgical concepts to sociology in The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life.
Identify this civilization sometimes named for its capital at Harappa but usually named for the river valley where its cities were found.

Indus Valley civilization. This other city of the Indus Valley civilization has a name meaning "mound of the dead" and contains a notable flush-toilet system. The "College of Priests" here are found next to its Great Bath.
Warsaw Pact. This Warsaw Pact nation was led by Nicolae Ceausescu following the death of Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej. It withdrew from the Pact following revolts in Timisoara.
Pygmalion. Both Major Barbara and Pygmalion were written by this Irish playwright, whose other works include Arms and the Man and Caesar and Cleopatra.

Xanthias [do not accept "Xanthus"]. This Ancient Greek comic playwright had his work adapted into a disastrous 1974 musical in New Haven, where the title croaking chorus of his The Frogs was played by the Yale varsity swim team and water splashed out of the pool, forcing several actors to perform on tiptoe.
Aristophanes. Another Xanthias serves Anticleon in this other Aristophanes play, which centers on a mock-trial wherein a household dog accuses another of stealing cheese.
O Guarani [or The Guarani Indian]. O Guarani is set in this country. Machado de Assis was another author from this country, whose literature is usually written in Portuguese.
answer: Federative Republic of Brazil [or RepÃºblica Federativa do Brasil]

question: Philip II of Spain. The Treaty of Müster that ended the Eighty Years’ War was part of the Peace of Westphalia that ended this other conflict, which resulted in the death of Gustavus Adolphus at Luetzen.
Silas Marner: The Weaver of Raveloe. This author of Silas Marner wrote of how a clause in Edward Casaubon's will makes it difficult for  Dorothea Brooke to remarry in her novel Middlemarch.
Identify this play in which Vladimir and Estragon meet Pozzo and Lucky while doing the title action.
answer: Waiting for Godot [or En attendant Godot]

question: Waiting for Godot [or En attendant Godot]. Murphy and Endgame are plays that exemplify this Irish dramatist's obsession with chess. He wrote Waiting for Godot and Krapp's Last Tape.
the Miller. This man, the author of the Canterbury Tales, based the awkward narrator on himself. This poet also wrote The Parliament of Fowls and The Romance of the Rose.

the hound of the Baskervilles. The true nature of the hound of the Baskervilles is discovered by this cocaine enthusiast, who died at Reichenbach Falls in "The Final Problem" but was resurrected by Arthur Conan Doyle after a public outcry.

Roger Brooke Taney ["tawny"]. This Democratic president nominated Roger Taney as Secretary of the Treasury and engaged in a long battle with Nicholas Biddle to destroy the Second Bank of the United States.

[Thomas] Woodrow Wilson. The eugenicist Margaret Sanger founded this organization to promote access to birth control. A branch of this organization sued restrictions on abortions imposed by the state of Pennsylvania in 1992.
answer: Planned Parenthood Federation of America [or PPFA]

question: Erewhon: or, Over the Range. Erewhon is by this author of The Way of All Flesh, who thought that the Odyssey was written by a woman.
Countess Ellen Olenska [accept either name]. The Age of Innocence is a novel by this New Yorker, who created the town of Starkfield as the setting for her novel Ethan Frome.
Ludwig Eduard Boltzmann. The ideal gas law can be derived from this theorem, which states that in thermal equilibrium, molecules have the same average energy associated with each degree of freedom.
Name this country of Harold Holt that was led during most of World War II by John Curtin, who sought to defend it from a Japanese invasion.
Name this militaristic Greek city state, a rival of Athens. A king of this city, Leonidas, led forces at the Battle of Thermopylae.
Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui [or Pachacutec; or Pachacutiq Inka Yupanki]. Pachacuti was the greatest ruler of this Andean empire, which was conquered by Francisco Pizarro.
Carnation Revolution [or Revolução dos Cravos]. The Carnation Revolution began in Lisbon and ended the Estado Novo of this Iberian country, which had long been ruled by Antonio Salazar.
answer: Portugal [accept Portuguese Republic or República Portuguesa]

question: Middlemarch: A Study of Provincial Life. This Victorian-era author wrote Middlemarch. She also wrote about how the orphan Eppie alters the life of the title “Weaver of Raveloe” in Silas Marner.
War Requiem. The War Requiem was created by this British composer of The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra.

"Young Goodman Brown". "Young Goodman Brown" was included in Mosses from an Old Manse, a short story collection by this author. Other works by this author include Twice-Told Tales and The House of the Seven Gables.

Nathaniel Hawthorne [or Nathaniel Hathorne]. In this novel by Nathaniel Hawthorne, Hester Prynne has the title entity sewn onto her clothing after her adultery with Arthur Dimmesdale is discovered by Roger Chillingworth.
Name this Japanese emperor who faced the Satsuma rebellion and promoted modernization with  the Charter Oath during his namesake restoration.
Name this student of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great. His lectures from the Lyceum became such writings as Poetics, Rhetoric, and Nicomachean Ethics.
This author, who was born in Poland and immigrated to the U.S. in 1935, wrote about Yasha Mazur in The Magician of Lublin. He also wrote the short story "Gimpel the Fool."

Isaac Bashevis Singer. Singer wrote almost exclusively in this language. It's not Hebrew, but this language also appears in the title of a Michael Chabon novel about a "policemen's union" in a Jewish state in Alaska and is the historical language of Ashkenazi Jews.

sonnet [accept Shakespearean sonnet or English sonnet; do not accept other forms like "Petrarchan sonnets"]. Another form of sonnets is named for this Italian author. Many of this author's sonnets are collected in Il Canzoniere, which is sometimes called his "song book."
answer: Petrarch [or Francesco Petrarca; accept Petrarchan sonnet]

question: war [prompt on general answers, such as "conflict"]. This Dutch theologian and jurist attempted to ground principles of just war in natural law. His book On the Law of War and Peace is considered a foundational text on international law.
answer: Hugo Grotius [or Hugo de Groot; or Huig de Groot]

question: London. During the Great Stink, many scientists proposed that the fumes caused this disease, even though John Snow had proven this intestinal infection to be waterborne while studying the Broad Street outbreak four years earlier.
beheading [or decapitation]. Lancelot's encounter with the red-girdled knight is probably derived from an earlier depiction of this Arthurian knight's beheading game with the Green Knight.
Death and the King's Horseman. Death and the King's Horseman is a play by this Nobel Laureate and author of Season of Anomie and The Lion and the Jewel.

gluon lines [prompt on "gluon"]. The OZI rule is useful in the analysis of decays governed by this force, whose carrier is the gluon. This force holds quarks together in nucleons and is described by quantum chromodynamics.
answer: strong interaction [or strong nuclear force; accept color force]

question: Wilt Chamberlain [or Wilt the Stilt]. The Wilt Chamberlain argument appears in this libertarian tome by Robert Nozick, which is a takedown of John Rawls's A Theory of Justice.
Zealand [do not accept "New Zealand"]. This most populous city on Zealand is home to the Tivoli Gardens amusement park and the Edvard Eriksen statue The Little Mermaid.

The Cherry Orchard [or Visnevyi sad]. The Cherry Orchard and Three Sisters are plays by this dramatist. Nina falls in love with Trigorin and identifies with the title doomed bird in his play The Seagull.
the Bastille. The storming of the Bastille was an early engagement in this overthrow of Louis the Sixteenth and Marie Antoinette.
answer: French Revolution (or RÃ©volution franÃ§aise do not accept the "Reign of Terror")

question: Name this jazz instrument played by Gary Burton, and by the man who joined up with Gene Krupa, Teddy Wilson, and Benny Goodman to form the Benny Goodman Quartet: Lionel Hampton.
answer: vibraphone [or vibes; do NOT prompt on or accept "xylophone"]

question: vibraphone [or vibes; do NOT prompt on or accept "xylophone"]. Before joining the Modern Jazz Quartet, Milt Jackson played vibraphone in this trumpeter's sextet. This composer of "Salt Peanuts" is often credited with co-creating bebop with Charlie Parker.

(John Birks) "Dizzy" Gillespie. Dizzy Gillespie's most popular standard is perhaps this tune, co-written with Frank Paparelli. It features a bass ostinato that alternates between an E-flat seventh chord and a D minor sixth chord.
Name this social psychologist, whose "self-perception theory" argues that people infer their own attitudes from their behaviors, much as an outside observer might.

Daryl Bem. Bem's "self-perception theory" differs in its views of how people change attitudes from this psychologist's theory of "cognitive dissonance." He collaborated with Henry Riecken and Stanley Schachter on When Prophecy Fails.
"Crossing Brooklyn Ferry. "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry" is part of this Walt Whitman collection, a large chunk of which consists of "Song of Myself."

This author of The Canterbury Tales incorporated a fictionalized version of himself into the frame narrative. He starts to tell the story of Sir Thopas, but is stopped by Harry Bailey, who considers it "not worth a turd."
Steppenwolf. Steppenwolf was written by this German author, who wrote about a character who achieves enlightenment while working as a ferryman in the novel Siddhartha.
Herman Hesse. In Hesse's novel The Glass Bead Game, Joseph Knecht attains this title when he becomes "master of the game." This is also the name of one of the novel's published English translations.

The earliest known peace treaty was signed after the Battle of Kadesh by the Hittites under Hattusili III and the Egyptians under this pharaoh whose other accomplishments include the construction of Abu Simbel.
answer: Ramesses II [or Ramesses the Great; prompt on “Ramesses”]

question: Charley. Travels With Charley is a critique of changing America by this author of Sea of Cortez and The Wayward Bus
Identify this member of the Ba’ath Party and former president of Iraq, whose regime was toppled after a US invasion in 2003.
Leopold Bloom [or Leopold Bloom]. Leopold Bloom is the protagonist of this modernist novel by James Joyce set in Dublin on June 16, 1904, and loosely based on the Odyssey.
Puerto Rico. This island contains the most speakers of the creole language Papiamento. This westernmost of the Netherlands Antilles lies outside the hurricane belt and has its capital at Oranjestad.
Nineteen Eighty-Four. This English author wrote Nineteen Eighty-Four and a novel in which Snowball and Napoleon seize control over the other animals after Old Major dies, Animal Farm.

calculus. Idiotic French revolutionary Jean-Paul Marat advanced a number of bogus theories refuted by this scientist, who figured out oxygen aids in combustion. The price of success? His head, in 1794.
Name this Aldous Huxley novel set in a dystopian future, into which John the Savage fails to acclimate.
Pierre Clastres. This psycholinguist argued that violence has declined over time in The Better Angels of Our Nature. He argues for nativism in books like The Language Instinct and The Blank Slate.

The title character of this Samuel Richardson novel is kidnapped, held captive, and almost raped by Mr. B; naturally, they end up happily married at the end of this novel, which is subtitled "Virtue Rewarded."
Pamela; or, Virtue Rewarded. This female author of novels like Cecilia and Camilla wrote about a "Young Lady's Entrance into the World" in the imaginatively titled Evelina.
answer: Frances Burney [or Madame d'Arblay; accept "Fanny" for "Frances"]

question: Transfigured Night [or Verklarte Nacht]. This one-act monodrama for a solo soprano depicts the interior monologue of a woman looking for her lover in a forest. The score has no organized repetition and has no formal structural organization, mimicking the stream-of-consciousness state it represents.
Erwartung [or Expectation]. Transfigured Night and Erwartung were both composed by this Austrian composer who invented the twelve-tone system.

rondo [or rondeau]. Some information about the violin concerti actually comes to us from correspondence with this writer of an influential violin textbook and composer of the Toy Symphony, who was Mozart's father.
answer: Johann Georg Leopold Mozart [prompt on L Mozart; prompt on Mozart]

question: The End of the Affair. The End of the Affair was written by this Catholic convert, a British novelist who also wrote The Power and the Glory, Our Man in Havana, and The Quiet American.
Graham Greene [or Henry Graham Greene]. In this Greene novel, cafe owner Ida Arnold investigates the murder of Fred Hale, a newspaper reporter, by the sociopathic gang leader Pinkie Brown.

question: Heart of Darkness. Heart of Darkness was written by this Polish-born author of Nostromo and Lord Jim.
Josef Tedor Konrad Nalecz Korzeniowski. This manager of the Inner Station, in attempting to convert the natives, ended up becoming as savage as them.

Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra [or Berliner Philharmoniker]. AdÃ¨s's professorship at the Royal Academy of Music is named for this composer of the solo oboe work Six Metamorphoses after Ovid and War Requiem.
Vassily Vassilyevich Kandinsky. Kandinsky co-founded this Munich art movement, other members of which included Franz Marc and Auguste Macke.

question: Hathor [or Hesat]. The Sacred Marriage ceremony took place between Hathor and this falcon-headed god who represented Lower Egypt in a long-running battle with Set. He's the son of Isis and Osiris.

postcolonialism [or postcolonial studies]. Frantz Fanon advocated striving for a "collective catharsis" through violent resistance to colonialism in this posthumously published work about the Algerian fight for independence.

capabilities [or capability]. The capability approach was first developed by this Indian economist and philosopher, whose Poverty and Famines argues that to understand famine, we must consider entitlements as well as food supply.
Identify this jazz clarinetist who played in combos he called the Gramercy Five. His big band recorded a popular version of Cole Porter's "Begin the Beguine."

Cristero War [or La Cristiada]. The Cristero War occurred in this country, where the adoption of the Constitution of 1917 preceded the election of Venustiano Carranza. The Ten Tragic Days occurred during this country's early twentieth-century revolution.

question: Name this speech, which criticized the permitting of an "annual inflow of some 50,000 dependants" and states that "As I look ahead, I am filled with foreboding" before comparing the speaker to a Roman.
"Grass". The Potato Face Blind Man, an inhabitant of the town of Liver-and-Onions, narrates the tall tales in this 1922 Sandburg collection, the first of the works he wrote for his three daughters.

knowledge [or episteme]. In a book named after this ethical theory, John Stuart Mill wrote that it was first stated by Socrates to Protagoras. This ethical view advocates the greatest happiness for the greatest number.

answer: The Unbearable Lightness of Being [or Nesnesitelna Lekhost Byti or L'Insoutenable Legerite]

question: Czech Republic [prompt on "Czechoslovakia"]. The Czech playwright Karel Capek wrote this play, in which the title characters are led by Damon and Radius in a rebellion against Domin, the husband of Helena Glory.
answer: Rossum's Universal Robots [or R.U.R.; or Rosumovi UniversÃ¡lnÃ­ Roboti]

question: wine [or grape vines; prompt on alcohol]. The Methuen Treaty promoted the exchange of English wool and wine from this country. A special fortified wine named after this country is produced in the Duoro region, which is close by to Porto.
Flambeau. Flambeau, Valentin, and Father Brown are all creations of this author of Heretics and The Man Who was Thursday.
pork. Pork is so popular in this country that it maintains a strategic pork reserve. This country also is home to a traditional method of preserving pork called Bakkwa.

Dead Souls [or Myortvyjye Dushi]. Dead Souls was written by this Russian author. This author also wrote a satirical play about a small town whose corrupt mayor and officials are tricked into thinking that Khlestakov is a government inspector.

the scientific image of man [accept "Philosophy and the Scientific Image of Man"]. Sellars compared his own philosophical project this German philosopher's attempts to bridge the noumenon and the phenomenon through transcendental idealism. He also argued for the existence of synthetic a priori truths.

median of medians algorithm [or BFPRT; or Blum-Floyd-Pratt-Rivest-Tarjan; or Blum, et al.]. The median of medians can be used as a selection algorithm for the pivot of this sorting algorithm, proposed by C.A.R. Hoare. Despite having a worst case of "big-O of n-squared," it normally performs faster than other sorts with the same best case of "big-O of n log n."
Dirac equation. Solutions to the Dirac equation predicted the existence of these particles, which have the same mass as their antiparticles the electrons but an opposite charge.

Name this play written by Auguste Strindberg in which the valet Jean decapitates a little bird after engaging in a scandalous relationship with the title character, who later decides to commit suicide with a razor.
Blood Knot. Blood Knot is a work of this South African playwright who also wrote about racism in Master Harold...and the Boys.
Name this husband of Georgia O'Keefe, who photographed working-class passengers boarding a ship in The Steerage.
The Joy Luck Club. : This author of The Kitchen God’s Wife and The Bonesetter’s Daughter also wrote The Joy Luck Club.

electrolysis. This man’s first law of electrolysis states that the mass altered at an electrode is directly proportional to the quantity of electric charge. His mentor, Sir Humphrey Davy, also used electrolysis to discover many new elements.
Identify this name, which was also borne by a hubristic son of Iapetus who was banished to Tartarus after Zeus struck him with a thunderbolt.

Constantine [accept Constantine XI or Constantine I or Constantine the Great]. Louis II of Hungary died while trying to retreat across a river after this battle, where he had been defeated by Suleiman the Magnificent.
Name this structure located in the back of the eye that contains photosensitive rod and cone cells.

the butterfly from The Butterfly's Evil Spell [or la mariposa]. This Spanish playwright of Blood Wedding wrote The Butterfly's Evil Spell. He wrote about a barren woman named Yerma before being shot on the eve of the Spanish Civil War.
"Howl". "Howl" was written by this Beat Generation author. Philip Glass' 6th symphony incorporates text  from this author's anti-nuclear poem "Plutonian Ode."

pragmatism [accept word forms like pragmatist philosophy]. This American pragmatist philosopher believed that learning should reward a “continued capacity for growth” and argued for a strong schooling system in his work, Democracy and Education.
An opium den run by "Old Fung-Tching" is the title edifice of "The Gate of the Hundred Sorrows", the first published story by this English author of Captains Courageous and "Danny Deever".

Federal Republic of Germany (accept Deuschland). This successor to Friedrich Ebert as President of the Weimar Republic dismissed Heinrich Bruning as chancellor and appointed Franz von Papen to succeed him.
The Eye of the Story. The Eye of the Story is a work by this author who wrote about Laurel Hand, who takes care of her father Judge McKelva in The Optimist's Daughter.

Eudora (Alice) Welty. In a short essay in The Eye of the Story, Welty replies to the question of whether or not a character is dead in this story in which Phoenix Jackson walks through the woods into town to get her grandson medicine.
Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (accept Lenin). Initially appointed as Minister of Justice under George Lvov [li-VOV], this man headed the Provisional Government that was overthrown by Lenin's forces.

Samuel Slater. Bagley went on to become the first woman employed in this industry. Its leading figure in the US was a virulently anti-immigrant, pro-slavery portraitist and candidate for mayor of New York, who refused to share credit with Alfred Vail for the invention that gave rise to this industry.

L'Enfant et les SortilÃ¨ges: Fantaisie lyrique en deux parties [or The Child and the Spells: Lyric Fantasy in Two Parts, or near equivalents]. This French composer set Colette's libretto in L'Enfant et les SortilÃ¨ges, though he may be better known for ballets such as Daphnis et ChloÃ©.
Martha Argerich. Mischa Maisky plays this instrument, which was also played by Gregor Piatigorsky. This instrument and the piano appear in all of Chopin's chamber works.
Name this Ligurian city, the birthplace of Christopher Columbus. This city had a longstanding rivalry with Venice over naval supremacy.
answer: Most Serene Republic of Genoa [or Serenissima Repubblica di Genova]

question: Name this poet who wrote that "malt does more than Milton can to justify God's ways to man" in "Terence, This Is Stupid Stuff," part of the collection A Shropshire Lad.
Name this rider of the bull Nandi. He and his wife Parvati are the parents of Ganesh, and he serves as the "destroyer" in the Hindu Trimurti.
answer: Shiva [or Siva; or Shiv; prompt on "Mahadeva"]

question: Shiva [or Siva; or Shiv; prompt on "Mahadeva"]. Shiva's older son is this peacock-riding god of war, who uses a spear called the Vel. This god once ran three times around the world during a race with Ganesh, who wins the race by running three times around their parents.
answer: Kartikeya [or Skanda; or Murugan; or Subramaniyan]

question: Sudetenland [or Sudety]. The Sudetenland was originally part of this country, whose president Edvard Benes wasn't allowed in the Munich Pact negotiations. This country later split apart in the Velvet Divorce.
Czechoslovakia [or Československo]. Germany also annexed this country in the Anschluss despite the opposition of Kurt Schuschnigg.

1812 Overture [or The Year 1812; or Overture of 1812]. Tchaikovsky also used "God Save the Tsar" in a festival overture on the national anthem of this country, honoring the birthplace of Alexander III's wife. Organists born in this country include the composer of Music of the Spheres and the organizer of several popular late seventeenth century Abendmusik concerts.

Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel. This Italian philosopher described the end of history as the condition of postmodernism in The End of Modernity. This student of Hans-Georg Gadamer advocates "weak thought," which eschews foundationalism for a multi-faceted approach to truth.
Beowulf sails south to help this king of Denmark ward off the monster Grendel.

Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary. This country was the instigator and loser of the second Balkan War. Byzantine emperor Basil II  earned his nickname by blinding thousands of soldiers from this country after the Battle of Kleidion.

Antinomian Controversy [prompt on Free Grace Controversy]. Another person banished in the wake of the Antinomian Controversy was this daughter of Francis Marbury. On the advice of Roger Williams, she settled in what is now Rhode Island.

"A Rose for Emily". This Southern author penned stories that often centered around the Compson family in Yoknawpatawpha County. In addition to writing "A Rose for Emily," he authored As I Lay Dying and Light in August.

William Cuthbert Faulkner. This novel by Faulkner focuses on four members of the Compson family, including the mentally handicapped Benjy. This novel depicts Quentin Compson's suicide after he is separated from his sister Caddy.

Anton Webern. Webern was a student of this inventor of twelve-tone serialism and leader of the Second Viennese School. He included a passacaglia about giant moths, "Nacht," in his early piece Pierrot Lunaire.
Name this Punjabi monotheistic religion. It reveres a chain of gurus starting with Nanak and ending with its holy book, the Guru Granth Sahib.
answer: Sikhism [or Sikh faith; or Sikhi; or Sikhs]

question: Name this empire, whose oldest major architectural landmark is the Haci Ozbek Mosque in Iznik, Turkey.

Ottoman Empire. This Ottoman architect used Iznik tiles extensively in the lower walls of the Rustem Pasha Mosque. The Mihrab of his Selimiye Mosque in Erdine is set in a apse-like chamber off the main hall.

question: The Death of Artemio Cruz [or La muerte de Artemio Cruz]. The Death of Artemio Cruz is by this Mexican author.
Mario Cavaradossi [accept either]. Mario Cavaradossi appears in Tosca, an opera by this Italian verismo composer of Madama Butterfly.
asiento. This British General won many victories with Eugene of Savoy, including at the Battle of Blenheim, a victory he commemorated by naming his palace after it.
answer: John Churchill, Duke of Marlborough [or John Churchill, prompt on just "Churchill"]

question: Tybalt. This character says that Romeo has a "serpent heart" when she hears that he killed Tybalt, before lamenting Romeo's banishment. In another scene, she asks, "What's in a name?"

jouissance. This French structuralist philosopher posited that a text may induce a feeling of jouissance in the reader in his book The Pleasure of the Text. This author of Mythologies analyzed five codes in Balzac's "Sarrasine" in his book S/Z.

consequentialism. This example of consequentialist philosophy has the maximization of pleasure, or "the greatest good for the greatest number" as its goal. It was advocated by Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill.
Pecola Breedlove [prompt on Breedlove]. Pecola Breedlove is the protagonist of this Toni Morrison novel, and seeks to acquire the title physical feature throughout.
Linkin Park. This other vocalist of Linkin Park is the band's rapper. He also founded the rap group Fort Minor.

The Life of Lazarillo de Tormes and of His Fortunes and Adversities [or La vida de Lazarillo de Tormes y de sus fortunas y adversidades]. While Lazarillo de Tormes was one of the first picaresque novels, Wikipedia claims that this novel is one of the last. The title character of this Alain-Rene Lesage novel kills all his patients while working for the bleeding-enthusiast Dr. Sangrado.
answer: Gil Blas [or L'Histoire de Gil Blas de Santillane]

question: Name this author of satirical science fiction-inspired novels like Slaughterhouse-Five and Cat's Cradle.
Kurt Vonnegut, Jr.. In this Vonnegut novel, Midland City Pontiac dealer Dwayne Hoover goes nuts after an encounter with the author Kilgore Trout convinces him that everyone but him is a robot.
answer: Breakfast of Champions, or Goodbye Blue Monday [or Breakfast of Champions, or Goodbye Blue Monday]

question: Herman Hesse. Herman Hesse also wrote this novel about a student at a monastery who becomes an artist after a Gypsy makes love to him. That student is contrasted with his teacher who becomes the head of the monastery.
answer: Narcissus and Goldmund [or Death and the Lover]

question: Name this country, whose democratic politics were interrupted by a 1926 coup by the "Sanacja" or "healing" movement. The general who seized power was the hero of a border war with this country's eastern neighbor at its birth.
answer: Poland [accept "Inter-war Poland," "Versailles Poland," or the Second Polish Republic]

question: Packingtown (accept Chicago, Illinois). Packingtown is the primary setting of this muckraking novel by Upton Sincair.
Name this general kind of largely percussion-based musical ensemble whose Javanese kind uses the five-note slendro and seven-note pÃ©log scales.
On the Beach. On the Beach is by this aeronautical engineer and novelist, who also wrote Round the Bend, No Highway, and  A Town Like Alice.
Nevil Shute [or Nevil Shute Norway]. Although born in England, Shute set many of his novels in this country, whose own novelists include Peter Carey and Thomas Keneally.
